Award.AwardTitle: Engaging Middle School Girls in Computational Electronic Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will engage middle-school urban girls in learning sophisticated computer programming and electronics within supportive communities where the learning is embedded in meaningful projects. The project addresses the national need to engage more girls in computer science and engineering. It is a hybrid online and school-based/out-of-school (OST) program that integrates programming and electronics through interactive narratives. The challenges will require coding, designing, circuitry, or fabrication for the solutions using e-textiles, an activity that should prove naturally engaging for girls. E-textiles are fabrics that enable digital components, such as LEDs, speakers, sensors, mini-computers and other electronics to be embedded in them. The use of commercial E-textiles is rapidly growing, ranging from e-textiles that enable health monitoring, monitoring the positions of soldiers in action, or monitoring of pilot or driver fatigue. Program challenges, presented through the iRemix online social learning network (SLN), will support participants in learning a skill so they level up (i.e., master a level in a challenge) and eventually earn electronic badges. For example, to level up in electronics, girls will have to learn the fundamentals of both series and parallel circuits. By developing their skills across these areas, girls will be able to create e-textiles. Participants will work face-to-face and remotely with peers and mentors on projects that are supported by the SLN and embedded in a compelling storyline. As girls level-up, they will unlock access to more advanced tools and a richer set of e-textile fabrication materials. Participants will be recruited from Chicago-area charter schools.

The project will investigate the hypothesis that the girls involved within this girl-friendly context will develop a mastery of these areas at least equal to boys and develop the perception that women can succeed and be happy in STEM careers. The research-based rationale is that interest in STEM develops through exposure to STEM in engaging ways and interest can deepen from a casual interest to well-developed individual interest through supportive activities that take place across time and space. The project will use a mixed-methods approach to research that will gather and analyze data regarding baseline digital and technical fluency, student surveys (access, experience and future possibilities, online activities, analysis of social network participation, and profiles of student engagement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Decisions about whether or not to pursue STEM learning and careers are made early. STEM professionals frequently link interest in their chosen field to childhood participation in informal communities and opportunities, such as messing around with technology tools at a friend?s house, a favorite after-school program run by a teacher, or a specialized summer camp run by a community organization. Unfortunately, despite living in a time of historic technological advancement, access to such learning communities and out-of-school program participation is not equitably distributed, and research has documented the growing gap between resourced and under-resourced families. In addition, contextual factors can discourage participation by underrepresented communities, such as a sense of fit, role models, and encouragement.


Research has revealed that intentionally designed interventions, such as design projects and the roles played by adults in the lives of young learners can mediate such challenges by supporting persistence through complex work, making connections between existing interests and available opportunities, and providing a sense of belonging. This ITEST  grant supported the development and refinement of Digital Youth Divas (DYD), a computational making program for urban middle school girls from underrepresented communities, particularly those who have not previously expressed an interest in STEM.


Building on over ten years of design-based implementation research by The Digital Youth Network, DYD's unique model creates a community of practice where girls connect both virtually and in-person with one another and their mentors while being exposed to scaffolded STEM topics, practices, and careers. The program has evolved to include five interconnected situational components: (1) project-based curriculum, (2) narratives, (3) an online social learning platform, (4) DYD-trained mentors; and (5) DYD caring adult network resources and workshops.


The curriculum integrates a series of interactive multimedia narratives, including videos, audio, and comic book representations, with computing and engineering challenges where participants can transcend levels and make progress on different learning pathways. The narratives are about recognizable middle school girls from a range of racial and ethnic backgrounds who have unique STEM "superpowers" (e.g., coding, designing, circuitry, or fabrication). The narrative-driven challenges situated in STEM in storylines model scientific talk amongst a diverse group of girls and encourage persistence and participation in scaffolded activities. Curricular resources are accessible and organized in the DYD online environment in a way that enables educators without the requisite STEM content-knowledge to implement localized versions of the DYD program. The online platform is a central hub where students launch activities, access resources, see examples and share work, and where mentors monitor participation and provide feedback and support. Together, these linked features created an environment where girls are encouraged to explore, level up, and persist in creating and sharing computational making, and see representations of themselves and people they identify with in models of computational work (e.g. mentors, learning resources, peers, field trips).


In addition to materials for youth learners, DYD also attended to the design of opportunities and materials for adults. DYD professional development opportunities supported adult facilitators to become productive mentors to the girls and to deepen their own pedagogical and content knowledge. Caring adult network workshops and resources empowered parents and other caring adults to support their students? STEM endeavors, broker new opportunities, and engage with and learn from each other.


Over the course of the project, over 350 girls from the Chicago area have participated in DYD programming. Approximately 65% of participants self-identified as African American and 20% as Latina. In addition, over 1200 middle-grade youth from Chicago and Evanston communities identified as having fewer computational making and learning opportunities have participated in events related to DYD programming, such as using a van to transport a mobile lab to different locations, showcase activities at citywide STEM events, and Hour of Code school-based opportunities).


Findings suggest that girls increased STEM knowledge of programming, circuitry, and computational thinking, and increased their confidence and agency in STEM work through narrative-driven project-based collaborative work. Also, adults from communities across the Chicago area developed pedagogical and technical skills to understand and support girls engaged in STEM learning through workshops, professional development, and related resources, including 34 young women trained as DYD mentors and 97 parents engaged in DYD Caring Adult workshops. Continuing to grow and adapt, DYD is currently being used in several locations. 


The results of this work have been disseminated in academic venues (e.g., conferences, journals) as well as practitioner venues (e.g., workshops at practitioner conferences for teachers, STEM advocates, and OST program mentors and leaders). We have conducted numerous professional development (PD) workshops for mentors, where they use our training material to prepare to lead cohorts of DYD students in their local areas. Outcomes including papers, presentations, posters, mentor training material, and examples curriculum are publically available at www.digitalyouthnetwork.org/divas.
